results.title: The Electric horseman
results.creator_credit: Ray Stark, Columbia Pictures Corporation, Universal Pictures, Wildwood Enterprises and Sydney Pollack
results.brief_description: When a has-been, drunken rodeo star reduced to starring in breakfast cereal advertisments finds out the multi-million dollar racehorse he is expected to ride for a publicity stunt has been drugged, he steals it, riding it out into the Nevada desert where it can recuperate. Seeing a good story, a newswoman (Jane Fonda) follows him, staying one step ahead of a posse of pursuing police. By the time they reach a remote rendezvous high in the Utah mountains, she is in love with both the cowboy and his convictions.

results.title: The Electric grandmother
results.creator_credit: Doro Bachrach, Highgate Pictures and Noel Black
results.brief_description: An adaptation of the Ray Bradbury story “I Sing the Body Electric”. A young family who lose their mother through death are subsequently delivered an electric ‘grandmother’ who seeks to provide for all their needs, both emotional and physical. This film provides an insight inside into child versus adult perceptions of growth, ageing, human relationships and man’s motivation for creating machines

results.title: The Electric company
results.brief_description: An example of children’s television programming, designed for children with short attention spans. A commercially structured, rapidly moving series of segments dealing with consonant and vowel sounds, word attack skills, structure and context analysis, rhyming patterns and punctuation. Featuring Morgan Freeman and Bill Cosby.

results.title: The Elderly are all of us, only a little older
results.creator_credit: Don Anderson, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Phillip Mark-Law
results.brief_description: Looks at the rehousing of elderly people in units with all modern conveniences. Follows the building of the units and the settling in of its new occupants together with their feelings about the move.

results.title: The Eildon story
results.brief_description: The enlarged Eildon Dam, Victoria, is a vast area of water, used to provide power and irrigation. It has become a water playground for boating, swimming and fishing enthusiasts. The film shows that although the dam has been completed, the Eildon township has been revitalised by the hardboard industry established there.

results.title: The Eight celestials crossing the sea = Ba xian guo hai
results.creator_credit: Manfu Qiu, Fujian Film Company of the People's Republic of China, Mingquan Ma and Yuntao Guo
results.brief_description:
‘Eight Immortals Cross the Sea’ is a well-known story written by an unknown author in the Ming Dynasty. The legend is about the Immortals on a journey to attend the ‘Conference of the Magical Peach’, and on this journey they encounter an obstacle-the sea. Instead of going across by their clouds (the transportation of the immortals) their leader Lü Dongbin suggests that each of them should use their individual magical powers to get across. On their journey across the sea, Lan Cai He’s basket of flowers give off a glorious scent of youth and life; and soon, this irresistible scent reaches the Dragon Empress’s court in the sea. This particular day happens to be the Dragon empress’ birthday, so the court is in session to celebrate. She receives a special artefact, a mirror which has the ability to reveal all truths. Upon seeing her reflection, she laments on her aging face; declaring her sole desire to be youthful once again. The magnificent scent quickly overwhelms everyone, and they soon realise that it is coming from Lan Cai He’s famous basket. The flowers, known for its powers to restore youth and give life, prompts the empress devises a plan to steal the basket. A sea army is sent out, and after a heated struggle with the immortals, the basket is successfully obtained and presented before the Dragon Empress. Upon consuming a single petal, the empress’s white hair turns black; she is delighted by this change and is convinced of the petal’s power. But with the second bite, all traces of youth disappear, ugly boils appear on her cheeks and she feels as if she has been poisoned. Realising that the basket is controlled by a secret magic, the empress devises a plan to lure the immortals into revealing it. Back on the shore the immortals are in a furious frenzy over the treacherous act, each member devises a plan, based on their supreme wit and combating skills, to retrieve the basket. The rest of the narrative sees the clash between the immortals and the Dragon Empress.

Historical Background:
The Eight Immortals have been part of Chinese oral history long before they were recorded in the works of writers of various dynasties – Tang, Song, Yuan and Ming. In Chinese mythology the Eight Immortals are believed to know the secrets of nature. They represent separately male, female, the old, the young, the rich, the noble, the poor, and the humble peasant. Each Immortal’s power can be transferred to a tool of power, kind of a talisman associated with a certain meaning that can give life or destroy evil. In modern China, the Eight Immortals are still a popular theme in artwork. Their figures, in the form of pottery, paintings, and other artworks, remain ubiquitous amongst households across China.
The Immortals are:
He Xian Gu (The Immortal Woman): The daughter of a 7th-century shopkeeper, she accidentally ate a magic peach and became immortal. She is attributed by the lotus/lotus pond, which can cultivate people through meditation.
Cao Gou Jiu (The Royal Uncle Cao): Cao Gou Jiu is reputed to have been the brother of a 10th century Song Empress. He is attributed with a jade tablet which can purify the air. He is the patron deity of actors.
Li Tie Guai (Iron-Clutch Li): Skilled at magic he was able to free his soul from his body and aid and meet others in the celestial realm. He is represented as a lame beggar carrying a double gourd. The gourd, symbolising longevity and the ability to ward off evil.
Lan Cai He (The Immortal Hermaphrodite): Her/his attribute is a basket of flowers associated with longevity, which she/he carries to remind viewers of the transience of life and with which she/he can communicate with gods. She/he is variously portrayed as a youth, an aged man, or a girl; in modern pictures generally as a young boy.
Lu Dong Bin (The Chief Leader): He was an 8th-century scholar, who was a student of Taoism. Dressed as a scholar, he is honoured as such. His attribute, the sword, which can subdue evil, allowed him to travel the earth defeating evil.
Han Xiang Zi (The Philosopher): Han Xiang Zi is said to have been the nephew of Han Yü, a famous scholar of the 9th century. Among his special skills was the ability to make flowers bloom instantaneously and tame wild beasts.
Zhang Guo Lao (The Elder Zhang Guo): Zhang Guo Lao is reputed to have been a recluse of the 7th or 8th century. He is portrayed as an old man on a white mule, carrying a drum made of bamboo which can restore life to living things.
Zhongli Quan: Among his many powers were transmutation and the knowledge of the elixir of life. His attribute is a fan, which can bring the dead back to life.

Researcher’s Comments:
Rare film, not much information available.
Related to the story is the Chinese proverb “The Eight Immortals cross the Sea, each reveals its divine power” which suggests that every individual should utilise their unique powers to achieve a common goal. One of the foremost functions of myth is to establish models for behaviour. Since the figures described in myth are sacred, they are therefore worthy role models for human beings. The continual reproduction of this well-known folklore (since the 1930s countless films and TV serials have been made in the Chinese speaking regions-Hong Kong, Taiwan, China, Singapore) can be interpreted as a collective desire to uphold and reinforce certain social structures and ideologies.
The famous Fujian Puppet company are best known for their performances of classical Chinese stories/mythologies, accompanied by traditional costumes and lavish sets. Their production of the ‘Eight Celestials Crossing the Sea’, with its employment of Chinese operatic elements, illustrate the enormous versatility of the popular folk art.
(3 stars - Mary Chen; April 9, 2010)

results.title: The Eiffel Tower
results.creator_credit: Le Monde en Images and Alain Pol
results.brief_description: How four French alpinists climbed the Eiffel Tower - from the outside. Using rock climbing techniques, the party scales the steel girders to the top, 1,000 feet above ground level. In hot pursuit, an angry policeman ascends the tower by the more conventional stairs and lifts, but to no avail.

results.title: The Egg of oryzias latipes
results.brief_description: Artificial fertilization of the killifish. through constant research a method of artificial fertilization of the transparent eggs of killifish or oryzias latipes, in Ringer’s solution was discovered. The delayed-action camera shows the process observed through the microscope.

results.title: The Egg = L'oeuf
results.creator_credit: Pierre Moretti, ONF | NFB and Clorinda Warny
results.brief_description: The symbolic value of the egg throughout history is represented in this film in colorful animation without commentary. The importance attached to the egg as one of the realities of nature appears in the art and architecture of all ancient civilizations. In modern times it still holds a place in traditional observance. The animation artist develops this theme in colorful, surprising sequences. Film without words. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Effects of fire
results.brief_description: This proposed public imaging piece shows a series of close up portraits of domestic objects being burnt to abstraction, creating an inventory of domestic combustion in this piece. Punctuated with subtle yet deliberate, almost mechanised camera moves and cut in a very subdued fashion, this piece will be predominantly shot with a macro lens and will also be given a highly colour saturated visual treatment in post production.
